data.text:
“Kismet has not been written,” said Brooks Atkinson of The New York Times after its Broadway opening in 1953, “ it has been assembled from a storehouse of spare parts.” This might have galled Luther Davis, co-author of the book of the musical, if a strike had not delayed the review’s publication.

Meanwhile, this Arabian night had attracted a sufficient following to survive Atkinson’s sneer about “a display of wealth, but not a work of art”; 583 performances soon spawned a movie; and its US lyrics, attached to the Slavonic timbre of Borodin’s 19th-century music, went around the world, making Davis’s tale of Eastern intrigue best known for the song Stranger in Paradise.
